creator: sfhowes

content:
re :thunderbird update changed menu bar

The 'Menu Bar' is exactly the same as before, but when enabled, by default it is located below the new 'Unified Toolbar'. If you do not like this then you can move to above the Unified Toolbar. You will need to use the instructions at this link:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1422908

The 'Mail Toolbar' has been completely removed and replaced with the 'Unified Toolbar'. When you first see the new 115*, the 'Unified Toolbar' will only contain the Global Search. This means you will need to 'Customise' that toolbar - eg: add 'Write', 'Tag' etc To customise right click on Unified Toolbar and select 'Customise'

Here is a link you may find useful:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/unified-toolbar

Currently, the 'Get Messages' which you can put on the 'Unified Toolbar' only gets messages for all accounts. But people have been asking for this to be improved because it only gets for all accounts.

The 'Folder Pane Header' toolbar also has options: click on the 3 dot icon and select 'Show Get Messages' This will display a cloud-like icon. Right click on that icon and there is an option to select the account.

People are also asking for an improvement to this icon - eg: add text 'Get Messages' and also show the down chevon icon so people know there is a drop down option.

Hope this info helps.

content:
Not really helpful when you have kids etc who occasionally want to use the pc etc

You are basically saying I cannot let anyone use the PC ever in case they open the mail client. Seeing as sensative information can be included in mail e.g medical data, then the client should be protected by at least a simple password.
creator: nemo1966

content: Having separate access for children is a feature of Windows and highly recommended for situations such as yours. With separate accounts, you can prevent them from seeing your data. Doing that would ensure children would have no access to your data, whether in Thunderbird or elsewhere.
creator: davidsk

content:
OK windows has separate logins, but in real life it is not effective in a single home PC environment.

It would mean logging out of the computer every time I moved away from it, which would shut down any open programs and/or work.
creator: nemo1966

content: I respect your concern, but it's a possibility if you have a lot of sensitive material. However, we like to help people where we can. You might want to experiment with this FREE password utility at https://fspro.net/my-lockbox/ It will password protect any one folder for free - use it for the entire profile. It causes the folder to be hidden and you would need to unlock prior to starting Thunderbird and lock again when done. Otherwise, it would be difficult for an email client to protect all data components, since they are accessible outside the application. This utility eliminates the issue by hiding the folder. I did check the current status of the password control you prefer and it's been in discussion for over four years due to the many side questions it raises. That translates to me as a feature that is no on the immediate horizon. This will be my final comment, as this forum can do no more.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks for that. I'll have a look

However in 99.99% cases just a simple password that would not allow the program to start would suffice. Most people who are just being nosey wouldn't be bothered digging into data files to read emails, however if presented with the emails with easy access they will read them.

I just don't understand why a password can't be added. Just to stop the program opening.

Are Thunderbirds data/achive files encrypted or plain text?

Not at all. https://freewindowsvistatutorials.com/loginToWindows7AsDifferentUserSwitchUsers.php

If you really want proper security, Thunderbird isn't the place to enforce it.

content:
Ok. I have found the bug:

On macOS, if `print.prefer_system_dialog` is set to True, then it will print nothing (to a printer nor to a PDF) when printing from Compose mode.

However, if `print.prefer_system_dialog` is set to False, then it will work. Of course, this introduces (seemingly unnecessary) additional steps in order to print to a PDF this way. Because with this False, you invoke File > Print, then (with the mouse) have to click "Print using the system dialog", and THEN choose the PDF option from there.

For clarity: either way, I'm getting to the system dialog, but it seems the rendering of the message only properly happens if I first detour through Thunderbird's dialog.

Is it possible to remedy this so that we can just skip the Thunderbird dialog and yet still print from Compose view?
creator: DaveTheNerd

content:
Gmail automatically substitutes the User Name of the smtp for the User Name of the sending account if they are different. You should have separate smtp servers for each account, and set each account to send on its corresponding smtp.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593

content:
First, there is no official support for reverting to a prior version, and the process is known to be somewhat problematic. Before proceeding, I encourage you to do a full backup. Here are the steps: Try: 

   Exit Thunderbird if running.    click windows key and 'r' key    Enter: thunderbird.exe -P --allow-downgrade    click on 'OK'

My suggestion is to stay with 115 and work through the various settings to see if you can find a workable approach. Can you post a screenshot of a 102 setup or somehow show in graphics what your setup was?
creator: davidsk

content: I assume you did that in config editor? If so, locate the prefs.js in the profile. It is a simple text file, so do not open it with a word processor. Notepad or the like is preferred. Locate the config entry that you modified and change to a more realistic number. Do this when Thunderbird is not running. To be safe, copy the file before you change it.
creator: davidsk

content:
Well, you have them each configured differently, so it's difficult to see which is preferred. Both of those must have been beta versions. Since 115 is the released version, you may want to see if it serves your need. Although I'm just a volunteer with no decision authority, my guess is that 118 is not going to revert to 112 settings.

Please also keep in mind that personnel on this forum are not decision-makers or developers. If you have specific suggestions to make TB better, please share that at connect.mozilla.org.

content: The last version of TB for OS X 10.11 is TB 78, but for 10.15, TB 115 is the current release. If you install 78 on both drives you might be able to share the profile with the help of Profile Manager. The drawback, of course, is that 78 is not updated, and might not work with some providers that require modern security or authentication standards. If you install 115 on 10.15, it will be difficult to share the profile with 10.11, but if the accounts are set up as IMAP on both drives, mail will be synced between the two without the need to share a profile.

content:
Right-click the Unified bar (the one with global search Ctrl+K), Customize..., drag the Tag button onto the toolbar. Tags can also be applied by pressing 1,2,3... for Important, Work, Personal...

Remote content is blocked by default, but when a message with remote content is opened, the Options bar should appear to allow or disallow the content. View/Message Body As must be Original HTML to view remote content.

I watched the video. The subject of being able to select multiple folders is under discussion:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1817605

A saved search is closer to what you want, as one can select any combination of folders to be viewed at once, e.g. you could have a Personal saved search that aggregates the Inboxes of all personal accounts, and a Work saved search that aggregates all work account Inboxes. Unified view collects all folders from all accounts in a single view, for the Inboxes, Sent folders etc. Unless you wish to apply filters, select 'Match all messages' in the saved search dialog.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Saved_Search
creator: sfhowes

content:
A couple of fried over on alt.comp.software.thunderbird helped me figure this out.

As soon as I set about:config "toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets" to "true", things started working.


My new user chrome.css:

/* ####### */ @namespace html url("http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml");


/* This borders */

  1. messengerBox { 
  border-right: 1px solid green !important;   border-left: 1px solid green !important;

}


/* set about:config toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets = True */ /* top down order */

  1. toolbar-menubar { order: 1; }

unified-toolbar { order: 2; }

  1. tabs-toolbar { order: 3; }


/* add a border to unfocused tabs for accent */ .tabmail-tab { border-radius: 10px 10px 0 0 !important; 

   border: 1px solid #aaa !important;    border-bottom: none !important; }
creator: margochester

content:
Look for the mbox files in the old profile, in Mail/<popservername>, ImapMail/<imapservername> and Mail/Local Folders, and in sbd subdirectories. They are the large files with no extension, named after folders, e.g. Inbox, Sent, Archive... Each mbox has a .msf index file.

Copy the mbox files, renaming if necessary, to Mail/Local Folders in the current profile, while TB is closed (ignore the .msf files). Restart TB, and you should see the folders under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.
creator: sfhowes

content: V mojom prípade Thunderbird súbory *.eml otvára správne a presne tak isto ako po mnohé roky - teda aj s predmetom. Asi sa bude treba pohrať s nastavením vášho ERP systému. Nemám k dispozícii váš ERP systém, takže nemôžem preveriť. Jedine, že by ste mi poslali nejaký pokusne vygenerovaný *.eml súbor.
creator: Ansamb
